channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Swiss Franc’s Pullback Likely Driven by Reduced Safe Haven Demand
item.description: The Swiss franc was slightly weaker against the euro and its recent pullback likely reflected a reduction in demand for safe havens rather than renewed SNB interventions, Commerzbank said.

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Slows, Leaving ECB in Its Good Place
item.description: The annual rate of inflation in the eurozone slowed in October to just above the European Central Bank’s target.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: More home-purchase agreements are being scrapped around the country, reflecting a growing standoff between buyers and sellers in a largely stalled housing market
item.description: Buyers worried about job prospects are getting cold feet, or realizing that costs will be higher than expected.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: China Factory Activity Gauge Signals Deepening Manufacturing Gloom
item.description: Economic momentum continued to weaken for the world’s second-largest economy, with a manufacturing gauge signaling mounting headwinds.

item.title: Japan Economy Shows Some Strength as Markets Weigh BOJ Hike
item.description: The Japanese economy is showing some signs of improvement, a slew of data indicated Friday, amid heightened speculation over the timing of the Bank of Japan’s next interest-rate hike.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Before coming to terms with China, the Trump administration was for months reluctant to reduce America’s fentanyl-based tariffs on Beijing
item.description: The Trump administration had for months been reluctant to reduce America’s fentanyl-based tariffs on Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Fed officials are planning to reduce the staff of its banking supervision arm by 30% by the end of next year, according to an internal memo seen by The Wall Street Journal
item.description: The reductions would leave the Fed’s supervision and regulation division with about 350 people.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: President Trump’s tariff rollout has taken numerous twists and turns since launching earlier this year. Here’s a roundup of where things stand.
item.description: A roundup of where things stand with tariffs on key U.S. trade partners and sectors.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham

item.title: The ECB held interest rates steady for the third meeting in a row
item.description: The European Central Bank held rates steady for the third meeting in a row.
item.dc:creator: Chelsey Dulaney

item.title: Japan’s Central Bank Holds Fire as Tariffs, Politics Cloud Policy Target
item.description: The Bank of Japan held rates steady again, as it waits for clarity on the impact of tariffs and a political leadership change in Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Number of U.K. Companies Hit by Critical Financial Distress Surges, Study Says
item.description: Of the 22 sectors covered by the report, 21 experienced a rise in critical financial distress of more than 40% when compared with the same period last year.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell delivered a blunt message for investors who have assumed the central bank would be on cruise control toward a third rate cut in December: Not so fast.
item.description: Powell forcefully warned against assuming another rate cut is a done deal as officials navigate an economy where spending is solid but hiring has slowed.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: President Trump said the U.S. and South Korea are close to completing a trade pact, a surprise breakthrough following months of contentious talks
item.description: The surprise breakthrough follows months of contentious talks over $350 billion in investments Seoul has pledged to America.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: Trump Expects to Sign China Trade Deal at Xi Summit
item.description: The highly anticipated meeting is expected to cover a wide range of topics, including the export of chemicals used to produce fentanyl.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: From Amazon to Target, the country’s largest employers are retrenching, laying off tens of thousands of office workers
item.description: Layoffs at companies ranging from Amazon to Target are sending young and experienced workers alike into an unwelcoming market.
item.dc:creator: Allison Pohle

item.title: The Senate voted 52-48 to approve a measure blocking President Trump’s tariffs on Brazil, with a handful of Republicans siding with Democrats
item.description: The measure, which now moves to the House and aims to end Trump’s imposition of tariffs under emergency powers, is largely symbolic.
item.dc:creator: Anvee Bhutani

item.title: President Trump’s ability to reorder global trade through personal diplomacy will be tested during his tour of Asia this week
item.description: The president’s ability to reorder global trade through personal diplomacy will be tested during his tour of Asia this week.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Watering down dish soap. Trading down to grocery discounters. Buying half a cow. Americans struggling with higher costs are going to great lengths to stretch spending on food and household staples
item.description: From buying half a cow to watering down dish soap, people are increasingly experimenting with frugality—and it is affecting sales at consumer companies.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan

item.title: In the nearly 250 years since the nation’s founding, technological leaps and demographic shifts transformed a scattered collection of farmers and laborers into today’s workforce of 150 million
item.description: Today’s Americans earn more, work fewer hours and are more likely to hold a service job than ever before.
item.dc:creator: Amira McKee

item.title: Inflation isn’t as high as many economists expected earlier this year, but that’s not much comfort for Americans still flabbergasted at the prices of necessities like food, housing and insurance
item.description: The news that inflation could be worse is hardly comforting for millions of Americans still flabbergasted at the prices of necessities like food, housing and insurance.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: U.S. And European Business Activity Pick Up in Continued Show Of Resilience
item.description: A rise in activity in the U.S., Europe and Asia indicates that the global economy remains resilient in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Retail Sales Rise for Fourth Straight Month
item.description: Retail sales volumes were unexpectedly higher in September, rising 0.5% on month, helped by tech stores and demand for gold.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Home sales rose in September to a seven-month high after buyers seized on declining mortgage rates
item.description: ​Sales r​eached a seven-month high, offering some hope that the housing market could be improving.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: PulteGroup Profit Falls as Housing Market Remains Stalled
item.description: PulteGroup recorded a lower third-quarter profit as affordability concerns continued to put off home buyers.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller

item.title: Why one company is investing in rural America instead of offshoring jobs
item.description: Instead of offshoring, Provalus looks for small towns where incomes are low and people are eager for positions that will teach them 21st-century skills.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: The number of unemployment claims filed by federal workers has grown sharply, reaching their highest level since a 34-day government shutdown that ended in January 2019
item.description: Data from states show that initial unemployment claims filed by federal government workers have jumped up this month.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Canada Existing-Home Sales Fall in September
item.description: Existing-home sales in Canada declined in September from the previous month, and prices fell to their lowest level in over four years.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: A reduction in the tariffs faced by Indian businesses exporting to the U.S. would likely boost growth this year, Reserve Bank of India Gov. Sanjay Malhotra said
item.description: Sanjay Malhotra said talks are under way to lower tariffs, and success would help lift the economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Upset over higher food prices, consumers are cutting back on purchases, stockpiling certain items or exploring more-affordable stores
item.description: Record beef prices and coffee that costs $1 more per pound since May have shoppers cutting back on some foods, stockpiling others.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kuo

item.title: U.K. Unemployment Edges Higher
item.description: The labor market loosened a little in the three months through August, with unemployment creeping up and wage growth slowing, as firms continued to hold back from hiring.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The man who won a record Powerball jackpot has a new goal: redevelop his hometown after the L.A. fires
item.description: Edwin Castro is one of the biggest investors snapping up destroyed properties—and he wants to lead in rebuilding his hometown of Altadena.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: A California new law to make it easier for developers to build multistory apartment buildings near major commuter stops, has triggered fierce opposition from Los Angeles and other coastal cities
item.description: Gov. Newsom Friday signed a bill that will make it easier to build apartment buildings. Cities like Los Angeles fear a loss of control.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kiernan

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Holds Steady in October
item.description: Economic sentiment remained grim but held steady near recent levels in October as a federal shutdown hampered government functions and sidelined thousands of workers, according to the University of Michigan’s latest consumer survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: IMF Chief Sees Global Growth Slowing ‘Only Slightly’ in Face of Higher Tariffs
item.description: The global economy is holding up better than expected in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries and the implications of technological change, the head of the International Monetary Fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Picks Up Pace as ECB Looks Set to Keep Rates on Hold
item.description: European Central Bank rate setters are sanguine about potential pressures on prices and expect last month’s rise in inflation to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: BOE Deputy Governor Sees Inflation Resuming Fall After ‘Hump’
item.description: The recent pickup in inflation, which is projected to hit 4% this month before declining, is unlikely to have long-lasting consequences, said Sarah Breeden.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
